title: HSS8005 {{< iconify line-md plus >}}
text:
Quantitative analysis 
        
        
            HSS8005 • Advanced stream • 2023
Newcastle University (UK)
        
        
            A second course in applied statistics and probability for the understanding of society and culture.
        
    




Module leader

   Dr. Chris Moreh
   HDB.4.106
   chris.moreh@newcastle.ac.uk
   tutorial booker



Teaching Assistants

   tbc
   tbc



Session details

   Thursdays 
   Lecture: 10:00-11:30
   Labs:   13:00-14:30 (Group 03)        14:30-16:00 (Group 04)

title: About
text:
About this site
Nothing important here

title: Data overview
text: We will be using a variety of real-world data from public sources and published research. You can read the data dictionary for each dataset from the side menu. You will be able to access the data from a dedicated  package {hss8005data} (note: work in progress and may be updated during the course).

title: Materials
text:
Materials for each week are available from the side menu.
Notes can found here: link to page

title: Week 1  Gamblers, God, Guinness and peas
text:
This week will be a general introduction to the module, probability theory, the history of statistics and the software that we will be using.
The labs will be an introduction to the {tidyverse} dialect of the  statistical programming language via the  API.

Please note that this plan and the content are still work in progress. The info sheets under  are available in a very rudimentary form, just to give some more boring details about how these planned topics map on to statistical methods that will be covered. The topics marked with an * have a very borderline-significant p-value when tested on the null-hypothesis that they have 0 probability of actually being covered in practice. It will depend somewhat on our interests and the pace of our progress through the previous topics.

title: Week 2
text: A broad review of simple linear regression modelling.

title: Week 3
text: Introduction/review of linear regression models with more than one predictor, with a focus on the concept of causation in a regression context and the use of directed acyclic graphs (DAG) as heuristic devices.

title: Week 4
text: An introduction to generalised linear models; logistic and count models.

title: Week 5
text: An introduction to the idea and elementary practice of statistical simulation.

title: Week 6
text: Introduction to time-series, maybe some spatial correlation and multilevel data amd models.

title: Week 7
text: Introduction to factor analysis and Structural Equation Models (SEM).

title: Week 8
text: Introduction to (social) network analysis and a little text analysis.

title: Week 9
text: Introduction to using text as data.

title: Week 10
text: Time for some conclusions and for hoping that we feel we have conquered some of the complications of applying statistical models to understanding human society and culture.

title: Readings
text:
Regression and Other Stories
Telling Stories with Data
Maximum Likelihood for Social Science
Beyond Multiple Linear Regression: Applied Generalized Linear Models and Multilevel Models in R

title: Readings
text:
History of statistics

Gelman and Vehtari: What are the most important statistical ideas of the past 50 years?
(Gelman and Vehtari 2021)

title: Readings
text:
Simulation and study design

https://iqss.github.io/prefresher/simulation.html#fnref27
Reinhart: RegressinatorR package
Data simulation in the context of multilevel regression and post-stratification: https://tellingstorieswithdata.com/15-mrp.html#simulation
Design and Analysis of Experiments and Observational Studies using R
The Survey Quality Predictor (SQP)

title: Readings
text:
Causality

DAGs: Deffner, Dominik, Julia M. Rohrer, and Richard McElreath. 2022. ‘A Causal Framework for Cross-Cultural Generalizability’. Advances in Methods and Practices in Psychological Science 5(3):25152459221106370. doi: 10.1177/25152459221106366.

title: Readings
text:
Network analysis

https://ladal.edu.au/net.html
https://bookdown.org/jdholster1/idsr/network-analysis.html

title: Readings
text:
Hierarchies

Sadler, Michael E., and Christopher J. Miller. 2010. ‘Performance Anxiety: A Longitudinal Study of the Roles of Personality and Experience in Musicians’. Social Psychological and Personality Science 1(3):280–87. doi: 10.1177/1948550610370492.

data: musicdata.csv
source: https://github.com/proback/BeyondMLR/tree/master/data
usage: https://bookdown.org/roback/bookdown-BeyondMLR/ch-multilevelintro.html#cs:music

Shakespeare, Austen, Bronte, Dickens data used in the context of multilevel modelling: https://tellingstorieswithdata.com/15-mrp.html#austen-bront%C3%AB-dickens-and-shakespeare
Deffner, Dominik, Julia M. Rohrer, and Richard McElreath. 2022. ‘A Causal Framework for Cross-Cultural Generalizability’. Advances in Methods and Practices in Psychological Science 5(3):25152459221106370. doi: 10.1177/25152459221106366. - also use multilevel regression with post-stratification

title: Readings
text:
Timelines

Bernal, James Lopez, Steven Cummins, and Antonio Gasparrini. 2017. ‘Interrupted Time Series Regression for the Evaluation of Public Health Interventions: A Tutorial’. International Journal of Epidemiology 46(1):348–55. doi: 10.1093/ije/dyw098.

data: sicily.rda
source: https://hbiostat.org/data/
usage scripts: http://hbiostat.org/rmsc/genreg.html#complex-curve-fitting-example

title: Readings
text:
Spacecraft

Spatial regression models
Spatial Data Science

title: Readings
text:
Text as data

Text Mining with R: A Tidy Approach (Dissferent Austen data used: https://www.tidytextmining.com/tfidf.html)
https://tellingstorieswithdata.com/16-text.html
Chris Bail: https://cbail.github.io/textasdata/

title: Readings
text:
Classification, ML

https://towardsdatascience.com/machine-learning-techniques-for-investigative-reporting-344d74f69f84 - a very interesting data analysis on Brexit voting prediction; unfortunately the dataset cannot be located, but may be reproducible from other sources.

title: Readings
text:
Intuition building

Hamming, Richard W. 1997. The Art of Doing Science and Engineering: Learning to Learn. Amsterdam: Gordon and Breach.
https://data-feminism.mitpress.mit.edu/
McElreath, Richard. 2020. Statistical Rethinking: A Bayesian Course with Examples in R and Stan. 2nd ed. Boca Raton: Taylor and Francis, CRC Press. - First two chapters freely available
Smoking debate:

See “The book of Why” for the story of how Fisher in particular was involved in the sceptical resistance to linking tobacco with cancer
Alex Reinhart: The history of “How to Lie with Smoking Statistics” - Daryll Huff’s involvement.
See also: Gelman, Andrew. 2012. ‘Ethics and Statistics: Statistics for Cigarette Sellers’. CHANCE 25(3):43–46. doi: 10.1080/09332480.2012.726563

Reinhart: Statistics done wrong

title: Readings
text:
R style guides

https://style.tidyverse.org/
https://google.github.io/styleguide/Rguide.html

title: Readings
text:
Project management

https://web.stanford.edu/~gentzkow/research/CodeAndData.pdf
https://learningds.org/ch/01/lifecycle_intro.html
Reproducible, transparent, credible research: https://worldbank.github.io/dime-data-handbook/
Quarto for Scientists

title: Readings
text:
Data sources

https://data.london.gov.uk/
https://i4replication.org/reports.html
Algorithmic Bias - full data and code
https://economics.mit.edu/people/faculty/josh-angrist/angrist-data-archive
https://economics.mit.edu/people/faculty/josh-angrist/mhe-data-archive
Norris, Pippa, 2020, “Global Party Survey, 2019”
Large-scale cross-cultural prosocial behaviour study:

House, Bailey R., Patricia Kanngiesser, H. Clark Barrett, Tanya Broesch, Senay Cebioglu, Alyssa N. Crittenden, Alejandro Erut, Sheina Lew-Levy, Carla Sebastian-Enesco, Andrew Marcus Smith, Süheyla Yilmaz, and Joan B. Silk. 2020. ‘Universal Norm Psychology Leads to Societal Diversity in Prosocial Behaviour and Development’. Nature Human Behaviour 4(1):36–44. doi: 10.1038/s41562-019-0734-z.
Data analyised by (Deffner, Rohrer, and McElreath 2022)

Simpson’s paradox:

Bickel, P. J., E. A. Hammel, and J. W. O’Connell. 1975. ‘Sex Bias in Graduate Admissions: Data from Berkeley’. Science 187(4175):398–404. doi: 10.1126/science.187.4175.398.

here - here


LEGO bricksets:

Peterson, Anna D., and Laura Ziegler. 2021. ‘Building a Multiple Linear Regression Model With LEGO Brick Data’. Journal of Statistics and Data Science Education 29(3):297–303. doi: 10.1080/26939169.2021.1946450.
Data and code: C:\Users\moreh\OneDrive - Newcastle University\DATA\Peterson, Ziegler (2021) LEGO data
